dt: {bc}having no element or part left out {bc}{sx|whole||}
{bc}having the margin continuous or free from indentations

pt: {sc}whole{/sc} {sc}entire{/sc} {sc}total{/sc} {sc}all{/sc} mean including everything or everyone without exception. {sc}whole{/sc} implies that nothing has been omitted, ignored, abated, or taken away.
{sc}entire{/sc} may suggest a state of completeness or perfection to which nothing can be added.
{sc}total{/sc} implies that everything has been counted, weighed, measured, or considered.

{sc}perfect{/sc} {sc}whole{/sc} {sc}entire{/sc} {sc}intact{/sc} mean not lacking or faulty in any particular. {sc}perfect{/sc} implies the soundness and the excellence of every part, element, or quality of a thing frequently as an unattainable or theoretical state.
{sc}whole{/sc} suggests a completeness or perfection that can be sought, gained, or regained.

pt.t: felt like a {it}whole{/it} person again after vacation

pt: {sc}entire{/sc} implies perfection deriving from integrity, soundness, or completeness of a thing.
{sc}intact{/sc} implies retention of perfection of a thing in its natural or original state.

et: Middle English {it}enter, entier, entire{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}enter, entier{/it}, from Latin {it}integer{/it}, literally, untouched, from {it}in-{/it} + {it}tangere{/it} to touch {ma}{mat|tangent:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: having no element or part left out : whole
